subject: RE: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Mmmh, let me make my point clearer then. The following four classes: ====== public class Test { private String m_name = Cedric ; ====== public class Test
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> > In JUnit, you have four ways to initialize / tear down your
> test, and
> > they are *all* equivalent:
> >
> > - At the beginning and end of each test method
> > - In setUp()/tearDown()
> > - In the constructor
> > - At the field declaration level
> >
> > I find that confusing as hell, so I *strongly* recommend to use
> > setUp/tearDown at the exclusion of everything else. Again, the idea
> > is to make the intent obvious.
>
> Actually, each of these methods is *not* equivalent

Mmmh, let me make my point clearer then.

The following four classes:

======
public class Test {
private String m_name = "Cedric";
======
public class Test {
private String m_name;
public Test() {
m_name = "Cedric";
}
=====
public class Test {
private String m_name;
public void setUp() {
m_name = "Cedric";
}
=====
public class Test {
private String m_name;
public test1() {
m_name = "Cedric";
}
====

are *all* running identically with JUnit: the field "m_name" will receive
the value "Cedric" before the invocation of each test method.

> setUp/tearDown: preferred, since exceptions are handled
> and propagated as test results; also separates setup/cleanup
> from the actual tests

Yes. Except that partial failures of setUp are not handled properly (and
they will flag all the tests as "FAILURES", which is incorrect: the tests
were simply not run and the error is in setUp(), not in the test methods).

Anyway, I think we are in agreement. Use setUp/tearDown for any code that
needs to be run before and after every test method at the exclusion of the
other three options.
